resources.name: Terrestrial
resources.description: A rocky planet with a solid surface, capable of supporting life. Terrestrial planets have a variety of environments, including mountains, oceans, and deserts.

resources.name: Gas Giant
resources.description: A large planet composed mostly of gases, with no solid surface. Gas giants have thick atmospheres and may have rings and many moons.

resources.name: Ice Giant
resources.description: A type of gas giant with a significant amount of water, ammonia, and methane in its atmosphere. Ice giants are colder than gas giants and have a solid core.

resources.name: Dwarf Planet
resources.description: A small celestial body that orbits a star but does not clear its orbital path. Dwarf planets can be rocky or icy and may have moons.

resources.name: Ocean World
resources.description: A planet covered mostly by water, with a deep ocean and possibly some islands. Ocean worlds can support a variety of life forms.

resources.name: Desert Planet
resources.description: A planet with a dry, arid environment, characterized by sand dunes and little to no water. Desert planets can have extreme temperature variations.

resources.name: Volcanic Planet
resources.description: A planet with a hot, molten surface, characterized by active volcanoes and lava flows. Volcanic planets are inhospitable to life as we know it.

resources.name: Frozen World
resources.description: A planet with a surface covered in ice and snow, often with a thin atmosphere. Frozen worlds can have subsurface oceans beneath their icy crusts.

resources.name: Exotic Planet
resources.description: A planet with unusual characteristics, such as extreme temperatures, unique atmospheric conditions, or unusual surface features. Exotic planets can be fascinating but often inhospitable.
